solely based cncf staff and there wasn't a lot of documentation and Clarity
regarding the procedures and how incidents were resolved and and there

available we produced were was a set of updates to the code of conduct itself there were a number of editorial changes
and refinements but essentially these are the highlights we clarified that the code of conduct applies to all
participants in our community not just contributors so that includes event attendees who may had not have made
their first contribution yet we've also added additional dimensions of diversity the commitment to make cncf a
harassment-free environment for everybody we also updated the scope to clarify that the code of conduct
applies not just in Project spaces but also in overall Community spaces so for
example at events or at meetups and also when an individual's words or actions are directed at or about a cncf project
the community or another Community participant because we realize there
have been a number of incidents in recent years that weren't weren't
clearly captured by the current uh by the uh by the current scope statement
also we added our welcoming and inclusive language to the list of examples of positive behavior
there were some additional examples added to the list of unacceptable Behavior including violence stalking
unwelcome physical contact unwelcome sexual romantic attention also providing
knowingly false or misleading information in connection with an incident and retaliating against a
person who's in good faith submitted a report or provided information as a witness
um we've also produced a jurisdiction policy
um that is quite detailed that describes which body resolves which incidence it
also outlines an appeal process there are some exceptions to each of these
um to these general rules but but in general a project level code of conduct
Response Team whether it be a committee or designated code of conduct responders they would be responsible for enforcing
the cncf code of conduct when an incident is occurring entirely in a project
the cncf code of conduct committee is responsible for resolving incidents when
they occur their incidents are either project agnostic so like for example if the the
um the conduct occurred uh in public or at an event or if it impacts multiple projects or if
the behavior occurred in a project that doesn't have its own designated code of conduct Response Team a vast majority of
CNC projects do not have their own code of conduct committee there are just a few that do
um and then there are some incidents that are resolved by the Linux Foundation primarily the events team
um and this uh this applies to incidents that happen on site an event that violate the LF events code of conduct
um and also if there's an event that there's an incident with a heightened risk of legal action or liability and
there are some of that some incidents that would violate both the LF events code of conduct and the cncf code of
conduct so those are namely events that incidents that occur at are in
connection with the cncf event like keep con and those would be jointly resolved by the Linux foundation events team and
the cncf code of conduct committee uh the jurisdiction policy also provides
appeal of Rights in very limited situations for example if it's
discovered that the project level code of conduct responders had conflicts of interest and didn't recuse themselves or
if um there is an outcome that's grossly disproportionate to the incident for
example uh you know mirror one-time rudeness you know and the person apologized you know that if they were

proportional to to the the incident the harm and a situation where the cncf code
economic committee might review an appeal from from a project level um outcome otherwise a cncf code account

responders and CNC of codecon committee would consult with LF legal on on what

for healing and resolution between the person who engaged in the behavior that
